What is binge eating disorder (BED)?

Binge eating disorder, now a distinct diagnosis in DSM-5®, is characterized by1:

  • Recurring episodes (at least
    once weekly for 3 months) of consuming an abnormally large amount of food in a short period of time (eg, within 2 hours), compared with others
  • Experiencing a lack of control
    over eating during an episode
  • Significant distress regarding binge eating

During a binge, adults with BED may consume food faster than normal, when not hungry, until uncomfortably full. They may also consume food alone due to embarrassment, and may feel disgusted, depressed, or guilty
after bingeing.

DSM-5 is a registered trademark of the American Psychiatric Association.

These are not the complete diagnostic criteria, but instead a brief summary. Diagnosis should be based upon a complete evaluation of the patient.

This site is intended for US health care professionals only.

Binge eating disorder (BED)
is a cycle of…

Binge. Distress. Repeat.1

Identifying and accurately diagnosing adults with BED is the first step to
helping them.

What is BED?

BED, now a distinct disorder in DSM-5®, is defined as recurring episodes (≥ once weekly, for at least 3 months) of consuming a large amount of food in a short time, compared with others. Patients feel a lack of control during a binge and marked distress over their eating. They typically experience shame and guilt, among other symptoms, about their bingeing, and may conceal these symptoms, even from you.1

BED affects nearly
3 million US adults2,3

Nearly 3 million US adults have BED.
Estimated 12-month prevalence in National Comorbidity Survey Replication of US adults aged ≥18 years, extrapolated to full US population aged ≥18 years.2,3
BED is the most common eating disorder among US adults and more than twice as prevalent as bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa combined2

The gender ratio is far less skewed in BED than in bulimia nervosa.1

Estimated 12-month prevalence
in US adults2:

BED: 2 to 1
1.6% of women vs 0.8% of men

Bulimia nervosa: 5 to 1
0.5% of women vs 0.1% of men

Data from an eating disorder–assessed subsample (n=2,980) of the National Comorbidity Survey Replication, a face-to-face household survey of English-speaking adults aged ≥18 years.

Prevalence rates are comparable among non-Latino white (1.4%), Latino (2.1%), Asian (1.2%), and African American (1.5%) adults in the US4

Sample from a combined data set of 3 nationally representative US samples.4

Caucasian woman
African American woman
Caucasian woman
Latino man

BED occurs with roughly similar frequencies in most industrialized countries (eg, Australia, Canada, many European countries, New Zealand, and the United States).1

In an online survey, only 3% of US adults who met DSM-5® criteria for BED reported being diagnosed with BED by a health care provider in the past 12 months.5
Data from a 2013 online survey of adults aged ≥18 years. Of 22,397 respondents, 344 met DSM-5® criteria for BED in the previous 12 months.5

Essential features
of binge eating disorder (BED)

In order to receive a diagnosis of BED, an individual must meet
the DSM-5® diagnostic criteria listed below1:

  1. Recurring episodes of binge eating are characterized
    by the following:
    • Consuming an abnormally large amount of food
      in a short period of time (eg, within 2 hours),
      compared to what others might eat in the same
      amount of time; and
    • Experiencing a lack of control over eating during
      an episode (eg, an inability to stop eating)
  2. Binge eating episodes exhibit at least 3 of the
    following characteristics:
    • Consuming food faster than normal;
    • Consuming food until uncomfortably full;
    • Consuming large amounts of food when not hungry;
    • Consuming food alone due to embarrassment; and
    • Feeling disgusted, depressed, or guilty after eating a large amount
      of food
  3. Significant distress regarding
    binge eating.
  4. Binge eating occurs at least once weekly for 3 months, on average.
  5. Compensatory behaviors are not observed like those associated with bulimia
    nervosa, and the binge eating does not occur during an episode of bulimia nervosa
    or anorexia nervosa.
DSM-5 is a registered trademark of the American Psychiatric Association.

Diagnosis should be based upon a complete evaluation of the patient.

Register to receive the
DSM-5® diagnostic criteria and additional BED information from Shire

What are common
triggers of binge eating?

As noted in DSM-5®, negative affect most commonly precedes a bingeing episode.1

Other triggers include1:

  • Interpersonal stressors
  • Restrictions on diet
  • Feeling bad about body weight, body shape, and food
  • Feeling bored
What are common triggers of binge eating?

BED onset occurs later than other eating disorders

In a survey of US adults, the median age of onset (21 years) was several years later than for anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa (18 years).*2

Median ages of onset and age-of-onset
ranges for BED, AN, and BN2

Median age of onset for BED is 21.

Median ages of onset and
age-of-onset ranges for
BED, AN, and BN2

Median age of onset for anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa is 18.

Interquartile range.
AN=anorexia nervosa;
BN=bulimia nervosa.

The mean duration of BED is
8.1 years.2

Adults with BED have other psychiatric comorbidity at rates similar to bulimia and anorexia1

Adults with BED often have coexisting psychiatric and physical conditions such
as bipolar disorders, depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, substance use disorders, and obesity.1

Lifetime BED comorbidity per DSM-IV® in a nationally representative
survey of US adults aged ≥18 years*2:

79%

met criteria for
at least 1 other
psychiatric disorder

49%

met criteria for
3 or more other
psychiatric disorders

Data from an eating disorder–assessed subsample (n=2,980) of the National Comorbidity Survey Replication, a nationally representative face-to-face household survey of English-speaking adults
aged ≥18 years.2

According to DSM-5®, a number of functional
consequences are affiliated with BED1

  • Problems with adapting to
    social roles
  • Quality of life and life satisfaction degradation due to health issues
  • Heightened medical mortality and morbidity
  • Heightened use of health care resources as compared to BMI-matched controls
  • Potential to gain weight and could lead to obesity

In a nationally representative survey of US adults aged ≥18 years2:

63%

reported functional
impairment during
the past year (Sheehan
Disability Scale)

19%

reported severe
impairment during
the past year (Sheehan
Disability Scale)

Data from an eating disorder–assessed subsample (n=2,980) of the National Comorbidity Survey Replication, a face-to-face household survey of English-speaking adults aged ≥18 years.2

While the exact cause is unknown,

Research suggests BED may have a neurobiological basis and genetic and environmental influences6-12

Prevailing theories that may support a neurobiological basis for BED:

Reward center and impulsivity dysregulation theory

Adults with BED have shown reduced activity in impulse control–related
regions of the brain6

Neurotransmitter
dysregulation theory

Dopamine signaling converts sensory stimuli into processes that may
generate or enhance “wanting” of a particular food7-9

Endogenous μ-opioid signaling dysfunction theory

Opioid signaling converts sensory stimuli into processes that generate
or enhance “liking” of a particular food8,9

Research also suggests that risk factors for BED may include:

Genetic influences7,10

  • BED appears to run in families, which may reflect additive genetic influences
  • Genetic differences in neurobiological components of the brain’s reward center have been observed

Environmental and social influences

  • In a case-controlled retrospective assessment of 162 women with BED,
    stressful life events were reported more frequently in the year preceding BED onset than in non-BED controls11
  • In a nationally representative survey of 5,702 adults, of the men (n=30) and women (n=75) who reported BED, 98% and 90%, respectively, reported experiencing some form of trauma*12

Types of trauma included combat experience, life-threatening accident, major natural disaster, and physical or sexual assault.12

Recognizing BED

DSM-5® defines BED as recurring episodes (at least once weekly for
3 months) of consuming a large amount of food in a short period of time, compared to what others might eat, with episodes characterized by experiencing a lack of control and significant distress regarding binge eating.1

These are not the full diagnostic criteria. Please register to receive the DSM-5® diagnostic criteria and additional BED information from Shire.

BED is different from
bulimia nervosa

It is not associated with compensatory behaviors such as purging or excessive exercise, or with dietary restriction, although frequent dieting may be reported.1

BED is different from overeating

While overeating is a challenge for many Americans, recurrent binge eating is much less common, far more severe, and is associated with significant physical and psychological problems.13

BED is different from obesity

As noted in DSM-5®, compared with weight-matched obese adults without BED, obese adults with BED eat more calories in studies of how people eat
and show1:

  • More functional impairment
  • Greater self-reported distress
  • Impaired quality of life
  • More coexisting psychiatric conditions

BED occurs in normal-weight, overweight, and obese individuals.2

Based on a nationally representative survey of US adults aged ≥18 years2:

<50%

Less than 50% of adults with BED are obese.

of adults with BED
are obese

Silhouette of a normal-weight male

19%

are normal weight
(BMI 18.5-24.9)

Silhouette of an overweight male

36%

are overweight
(BMI 25-29.9)

but not obese
(BMI ≥30)

Resources

This information may help you to identify and accurately diagnose adults with
BED in your practice.

Starting the conversation

These questions may help you begin a dialogue with your adult patients about their eating
behavior if BED is suspected.

General screening14

  • Do you worry that you have lost control over how much you eat?
  • Would you say that food dominates
    your life?
Adult patient with BED and her doctor

Specific for BED diagnosis15

  • Do you often eat within any 2-hour period what most
    people would regard as an unusual amount of food?
  • During these binges, did you eat…
    • Much more rapidly than normal?
    • Until you felt uncomfortably full?
    • Large amounts of food when you didn’t feel
      physically hungry?
    • Alone because you were embarrassed by how
      much you were eating?
  • Was it very upsetting to you that you couldn’t stop
    eating or control what or how much you were eating?
  • How often did you binge?

    and men? (00:34)
